channel.title: Learning Java, what kind of Dev Tools?
channel.description:
Alright, I got tired of reading this section and not knowing what the hell everyone was talking about. I went out and bought Sams Teach Yourself Java 2 in 21 Days. Anyways it lists alot of Developmental Tools such as: Borland JBuilder, Sun NetBeans, IntelliJ IDEA, and IBM VisualAge. So I was wondering what do yall use? The book also says that Java is easier to learn than C++, which is a plus because C++ is a pain in the ass. :P
Anyways thanks.

item.title: Learning Java, what kind of Dev Tools?
item.dc:creator: @pimjong pimjong
item.description:
@pimjong wrote:

[quote=“ruler, post:16, topic:1806”][quote author=Pwnd link=topic=1863.msg20170#msg20170 date=1146225121]

microsoft word to write java
javac to compile

the reason why i use word is its text to speeh, see while i am working, word can read back my program to me.
I also use eclipse, i recomend using eclipse because it is used in the workspace unlike others mentioned above. by workplace i mean Harris Corporation

you actually use microsoft word no joke?

You can’t use Microsoft Word unless he saves it as a .txt. The format that Word saves, as a default, adds a little more than plain text format.
[/quote][/quote]

Read full topic

item.source: Learning Java, what kind of Dev Tools?

item.title: Learning Java, what kind of Dev Tools?
item.dc:creator: @Krichevskoy Krichevskoy
item.description:
@Krichevskoy wrote:

I usually use IDEA for anything that I want to do major work on.
If it's not something big or I just don't feel like waiting on IDEA to load, then I use JCreator.
I do the same kind of thing with IrfranView vs. Photoshop - one of them is quick, but the other does work.

I am not an Eclipse fan, though it seems to have legions of devotees.

Read full topic
item.source: Learning Java, what kind of Dev Tools?

item.title: Learning Java, what kind of Dev Tools?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

eXemplar:

I use IDEA and notepad++, http://sourceforge.net/projects/notepad-plus

There's quite a few ide's around for java, but the main ones are IDEA, JBuilder, Eclipse and NetBeans. Personally I've used most bar Eclipse, and find them all good for different things, it just falls down to personal preference.

notepad++ and ultraedit32 are both good, I use them both depending on which computer I am on, exemplar got me to try Intellij IDEA, but I didnt like it very well at all

Read full topic
item.source: Learning Java, what kind of Dev Tools?

item.source: Learning Java, what kind of Dev Tools?

item.title: Learning Java, what kind of Dev Tools?
item.dc:creator: @Snipe Snipe
item.description:
@Snipe wrote:

I downloaded NetBeans and Textpad. NetBeans is pretty damn good if I wanted to make a big ass program later on but for right now I want something a bit simpler. I had Textpad along time ago and I liked it, but now it's not working. Everytime I try to save something it freezes up and I have to CTRL ALT DEL it. I finally found away to sorta of use it as a complier only. I have to write it in Notepad, save it, then send it to TextPad the compile and run it. It works just fine until I attempt to save it. I've deleted it and reinstalled it twice.

I'm gonna try JBuilder and JCreater in a bit. Anyone know a program like Textpad? I really liked that program.

Read full topic
item.source: Learning Java, what kind of Dev Tools?

item.title: Learning Java, what kind of Dev Tools?
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

Eclipse and Netbeans are great IDEs, but when I work I look mainly for speed and simplicity...so I mainly stick to Editpad for everything

I also use JCreator sometimes if I'm just working on a quick project...

Read full topic

I use all of them.
JBuilder is sexy, by the way.
